tossups.question: From 1978 to 2011, an NPR show focusing on this instrument was hosted by Marian McPartland. The 2016 album Everything is Beautiful, which remixes Miles Davis songs, was released by a player of this instrument named Robert Glasper. The best-selling solo album ever for this instrument is The Köln Concert. The band Return to Forever was founded by a player of this instrument whose album (*) Light as a Feather contains the standard “Spain.” Keith Jarrett played this instrument, which was also played by a musician who used turntables to open the song “Rockit.” An electric variety of this instrument was played by that man on the songs “Headhunters” and “Chameleon.” For 10 points, name this instrument played by Chick Corea and Herbie Hancock.
tossups.answer: piano [or keyboards; or keys; or jazz piano; or electric piano; or Fender Rhodes electric piano]
tossups.answer_formatted: piano [or keyboards; or keys; or jazz piano; or electric piano; or Fender Rhodes electric piano]

tossups.question: Mark Riebling's book Wedge advocated for members of this profession to be "more like spies" and helped popularize this profession's intelligence-led variety. Activists O.W Wilson and August Vollmer led an early movement to reduce corruption in this profession. Legal scholar Herman Goldstein is best known for developing the "problem oriented" version of this profession, which later gave rise to its SARA Model. This profession's (*) community form is based on building trust between practitioners and the people they serve. This profession should target minor incidents according to the broken windows theory. "Protect and Serve" is the motto of the people who work in, for 10 points, what profession which typically aims to reduce or prevent crime?
tossups.answer: police [accept word forms like policing; accept law enforcement]]

tossups.question: One character in this play throws socks at her husband, who then calls her his “little ducky daddles.” Since 1957, this play has been performed continuously at the Théâtre de la Huchette as the first on a double bill with another play that ends with the Professor stabbing the Pupil. Characters in this play debate on whether hearing a doorbell ring means someone is at the door. This play ends as the lights cut out and the four main characters shout (*) “It’s not that way. It’s over here!” In this play, which is set in a “middle-class English interior, with English armchairs,” the maid Mary recites a poem in honor of the Fire Chief, who interrupts a dinner between the Smiths and the Martins. For 10 points, name this absurdist play by Eugene Ionesco whose title references a type of opera singer.
tossups.answer: The Bald Soprano [or La Cantatrice chauve]

tossups.question: According to Plutarch, this man pretended to have diarrhea as an excuse to reveal Saturninus’ political plans to his rivals. This leader scandalized the Senate by presiding over it while wearing triumphal robes instead of a toga after a conflict in which his subordinate made overtures to Bocchus I. Metellus mentored this leader, who eventually fulfilled a prophecy involving (*) eagle chicks. This leader’s forces were defeated at the Colline Gate by a rival who ordered several proscriptions. This leader defeated the Cimbri at Vercellae, earning him the moniker “third founder of Rome”. This leader defeated Jugurtha and introduced the cohort in his namesake military reforms. For 10 points, name this Roman general and rival of Sulla.
tossups.answer: Gaius Marius

tossups.question: After one of these phenomena, Fresnel zones deform along the ray paths produced by high ray-velocity body waves. The square root of energy produced by one of the phenomena is proportional to the product of rebound strain and displacement. That relation was discovered by a scientist studying the differential motion produced by (*) ‘deep-focus’ examples of these phenomena, Hugo Benioff. Frequency is proportional to the “roll off” coefficients a and b in another law quantifying these phenomena.  That law’s namesake also developed a logarithmic scale quantifying the magnitude of these phenomena. For 10 points, name these events resulting from energy released along fault planes that are measured by the Richter scale.
tossups.answer: earthquakes [accept earth tremor; accept earth temblor; prompt on quake; prompt on tremor; prompt on temblor] , OSci>
tossups.answer_formatted: earthquakes [accept earth tremor; accept earth temblor; prompt on quake; prompt on tremor; prompt on temblor]

tossups.question: In one story by this author, a woman grows ill after believing her friend was reincarnated as an otter. In another story by this author, a mischievous boy pretends his grandmother is the “Evil One” and leaves her stuck in a rainwater tank. A third story by this author of "Laura" and "The Lumber Room" ends with the one-word sentence "Wolves." and tells of two men in a (*) land dispute who get stuck underneath a collapsed tree. Vera lies about a “great tragedy” in a story by this author whose last line is “Romance at short notice was her specialty.” In that story by this author, Framton Nuttel runs away after seeing men returning from hunting through the title structure. For 10 points, name this British author of “The Interlopers” and “The Open Window.”
tossups.answer: Saki [or Hector Hugh Munro]

tossups.question: Oscar Lawler was revealed to have authored a memo supposedly written by this president authorizing the dismissal of Louis Glavis. An assassination attempt against this U.S. president was stopped by Frederick Russell Burnham during a summit to resolve the Chamizal dispute. Prior to becoming president, this man removed Arthur MacArthur Jr. from command in the (*) Philippines. Conflict arose in this president’s cabinet between Richard Ballinger and his predecessor’s Secretary of the Interior, Gifford Pinchot (“pin-CHO”). This president met with Porfirio Diaz, and his administration saw the rise of dollar diplomacy. This man’s hopes for a second term were doomed by Teddy Roosevelt’s Bull Moose campaign. For 10 points, name this rotund president.
tossups.answer: William Howard Taft

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Cells with this general property appear red in Abcam’s blue, green, red fluorescence assay for detecting it. In flow cytometry, cells with this property will appear double positive for propidium iodide and annexin-V (“five”). It’s not related to cell size or the nucleus, but cells with this property are sorted into the pellet in Ficoll gradient centrifugation. When cultured, cells with the (*) opposite of this property will cause RPMI media to change color from pink to yellow. One process that induces this property exposes residues of phosphatidylserine, and assays for this property commonly test for cytochrome c in the cytosol. Induction of this property is mediated by caspases. For 10 points, name this property of cells that have undergone apoptosis.
tossups.answer: dead cells [accept apoptosis, necrosis, pyroptosis; accept descriptions indicating that cells are dying or undergoing apoptosis, necrosis, or pyroptosis]
tossups.answer_formatted: dead cells [accept apoptosis, necrosis, pyroptosis; accept descriptions indicating that cells are dying or undergoing apoptosis, necrosis, or pyroptosis]
acceptable: descriptions indicating that cells are dying

tossups.question: In the Theologus Autodidactus, Ibn al-Nafis argued that this concept is related "to the entire matter whose temperament is prepared to receive" this concept. According to Alexander of Hales, this concept would be "laboring under ignorance" if it was unaware that it was clean and was interacting with another, corrupt, entity. St. Augustine described this entity as a "special substance, endowed with reason" and Avicenna attempted to prove the (*) existence of this entity with his "Floating Man" thought experiment. Thomas Aquinas argued that this entity is non-corporeal and can exist independently of the body. For 10 points, name this metaphysical entity, which Pythagoras argued undergo transmigration and were immortal.
tossups.answer: soul [or spirit; accept psyche; prompt on the self]

tossups.question: A character in this film series butchers a joke by saying “Why don’t you make like a tree and get out of here.” Jules and Verne are the children of a character in this series who saves his wife from a train crashing into a ravine. Throughout this film series, the protagonist gets angry whenever someone calls him “chicken.” The line (*) “Roads? Where we’re going, we don't need roads” is delivered at the end of the first film in this series, whose climax occurs when lightning strikes the Hill Valley clock tower. In its second installment, a sports almanac makes Biff Tannen wealthy. In the first film in this series, the protagonist tries to ensure his parents get together after traveling in a DeLorean with Doc Brown. For 10 points, name this trilogy starring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly, who travels through time.
tossups.answer: Back to the Future [accept Back to the Future II or Back to the Future III]
tossups.answer_formatted: Back to the Future [accept Back to the Future II or Back to the Future III]

tossups.question: The mother of a rebellious, Johnny Cash-loving character runs a tattoo parlor in this city in a novel titled The Bastard of [this city]. In one novel, a preacher in this city believes coffee causes “ulcers, hernias, and sterility,” and his followers later burn down a coffeehouse. A character in this city falls in love with a lower-class shopgirl and collects (*) cigarette butts and other objects that remind him of her. Olive, Stork, and Butterfly are some of the suspected killers investigated by Black in this city. Death and a coin are some of the unusual narrators of that novel set here, whose first chapter is narrated by Elegant Effendi, a murdered miniaturist. This city is the setting of The Museum of Innocence and My Name is Red. For 10 points, name this home city of Orhan Pamuk.
tossups.answer: Istanbul [or Constantinople; the first novel is by Elif Shafak]
tossups.answer_formatted: Istanbul [or Constantinople; the first novel is by Elif Shafak]

tossups.question: Thousands of protesters in this country gathered at its Goethe Institute for a massive 10-day poetry festival. An article about this country’s “Red and Black Colonization” sparked protests against this country’s government, which operated Evin Prison. Over 40 people died watching The Deer in the Cinema Rex Fire in this country. Tony (*) Mendez created a fake film in this country in a plot called the Canadian Caper. Cyrus Vance resigned after an operation in this country termed “Eagle Claw”. This country’s SAVAK secret police enforced secularization during the White Revolution. The Pahlavi dynasty ended in this country after the rise of Ruhollah Khomeini. For 10 points, name this country where a 444-day hostage crisis when Ronald Reagan became president.
tossups.answer: Iran

tossups.question: One painting by this artist inspired a photograph in which leaves from two dead trees and paper thrown into the air are caught by the title Sudden Gust of Wind. In that original painting by this artist, two men clutch their hats while a third man watches his trilby blow away. In another work by this artist, three men camp alongside the banks of a waterfall emerging from a circular cliffside opening. According to legend, this artist chased a (*) chicken with red paint on its feet across a canvas to create one landscape. An elderly cooper constructs an unusually large barrel in the foreground of another painting by this artist. Small boats are threatened by the title force of nature with Mount Fuji in the background in this artist’s best-known work. For 10 points, name this Japanese ukiyo-e (“YOO-kee-OH-ey”) printmaker of Great Wave of Kanagawa.
tossups.answer: Katsushika Hokusai (the unnamed Hokusai works in power are Travellers Caught in a Sudden Breeze at Ejiri and The Waterfall of Amida behind the Kiso Road)
tossups.metadata: the unnamed Hokusai works in power are Travellers Caught in a Sudden Breeze at Ejiri and The Waterfall of Amida behind the Kiso Road

tossups.question: A set of compositions named for this literary character may have initially included the Bagatelle without Tonality. This character titles a work that opens with repeated eighth notes on “E,” that sequentially adds B, F-sharp, and then C-sharp to create quintal chords representing the tuning of a fiddle. Lyrics sung by this literary character are the basis for Mussorgsky’s “Song of the Flea.” This character titles the only opera with music composed by librettist (*) Arrigo Boito (“bow-EE-toe”). The first piece in a set of works named for this character is subtitled “Dance in the Village Inn”. In a Hector Berlioz “dramatic legend,” this character tricks Marguerite into killing her mother. For 10 points, name this character who titles four waltzes by Franz Liszt and is the antagonist of Berlioz’s The Damnation of Faust.
tossups.answer: Mephistopheles [or Mephisto; or Mefistofele]

tossups.question: One of these works supposedly transcribed from the Akashic Chronicle by Levi Dowling is named for the astrological sign that it was written under. J.G. Körner used the term "agrapha" to refer to phrases not included in these works. The Diatessaron of Tatian is the earliest known attempt to harmonize these works. A piece of wisdom literature that is one of these works is was recovered from the (*) Nag Hammadi library and is associated with the Gnostic tradition. The Q Source is a hypothetical source for these texts, which helps solve their Synoptic problem. The collective name for these texts means "good news." For 10 points, name these texts which depict the life of Jesus and include ones named for Thomas, Luke, and John.
tossups.answer: Gospels [accept non-canonical Gospels prompt on Books of the Bible or Books of the New Testament; prompt on biographies of Jesus or similar answers]
tossups.answer_formatted: Gospels [accept non-canonical Gospels prompt on Books of the Bible or Books of the New Testament; prompt on biographies of Jesus or similar answers]
acceptable: non-canonical Gospels prompt on Books of the Bible

tossups.question: The Nahm transform is an alternative to Ward’s twistor construct for modeling the behavior of these particles. An equation whose right-hand side multiplies the Hodge star operator on a 3-manifold, M, with the adjoint bundle, phi, was created to characterize these particles by Bogomolny. One of these particles may arise for a gauge group coupled to a spontaneously breaking-down Higgs field in a special case of Yang-Mills theory described by (*) t’Hooft and Polyakov. A non-reproducible observation of this particle was reported by Blas Navarro on Valentine’s Day 1982. Dirac conjectured that the existence of this particle would be a violation of Gauss’ law of magnetism. For 10 points, name these hypothetical elementary particles with only a north or south pole.
tossups.answer: magnetic monopole

tossups.question: In one passage, this character asks “what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it [that] commands” him. This character makes a speech describing a “little lower layer” before stating “If man will strike, strike through the mask!” One character has a dream where he repeatedly kicks this man, who has turned into a pyramid. This character asks the blacksmith Perth to forge a weapon he (*) baptizes in blood, and he befriends the African-American boy Pip. His death is prophesied by a Parsee named Fedallah. This Quaker yells “From hell’s heart I stab at thee!” before throwing his harpoon at a creature that had earlier bit off his leg. For 10 points, name this captain of the Pequod who pursues the whale Moby Dick.
tossups.answer: Captain Ahab

tossups.question: One river of this name is fed by the Concho River, which is named for its abundant Tampico pearly mussels. That river of this name flows through the reservoirs of Lake Lyndon B. Johnson and Lady Bird Lake on its way to Matagorda Bay. That river of this name flows through Austin and is the longest river entirely within Texas. Another river of this name flows through De Beque Canyon and waters the (*) Grand Valley Region. The Salton Sea was created by a river of this name, which also forms Lake Powell behind the Glen Canyon Dam. Lake Mead is formed along a river of this name behind the Hoover Dam. For 10 points, give this name of the river that carved out the Grand Canyon.
tossups.answer: Colorado River

tossups.question: A queen of this dynasty tried to kill her daughter Rigunth by telling her to reach into a chest to pick out jewels and then slamming the lid of the chest on her neck. The founder of this dynasty composed a law code that defines the chrenecruda. That ruler’s victory against Syagrius was documented in a history of this dynasty by (*) Gregory of Tours. Napoleon was inspired by golden bees found in this dynasty’s royal tomb when creating his imperial cloak. This dynasty was supposedly descended from the Quinotaur, a sea monster. The founder of this dynasty won at Soissons and codified Salic Law. For 10 points, name this dynasty founded by Clovis in modern-day France.
tossups.answer: Merovingian Dynasty

tossups.question: Proteins tagged with the chelating complex DOTA and various lanthanides are analyzed with this technique in MeCAT. A variant of this technique passes its sample through a nebulizer before adding it to an argon plasma, and makes use of a Daly detector and a Faraday cup. After heating its liquid sample with a metal filament that device for this technique has an output that is analyzed with the (*) Saha equation. Devices for performing this technique are commonly coupled with laser ablation systems or devices that output a Taylor cone. Identification of the M+1 signal and the base peak are relevant to analysis in this technique. For 10 points, name this technique that separates fragmented ions by the ratio of its namesake quantity to charge.
tossups.answer: mass spectrometry [accept ICP-MS or TIMS or inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry or thermal ionization mass spectrometry; accept spectroscopy in place of spectrometry; prompt on ESI or MALDI or (soft) ionization with “is used as a step in what other technique?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: mass spectrometry [accept ICP-MS or TIMS or inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry or thermal ionization mass spectrometry; accept spectroscopy in place of spectrometry; prompt on ESI or MALDI or]

bonuses.leadin: The Incroyables and Merveilleuses subculture developed during this specific period, in which men wore their hair down the sides in a style called “dog ears”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this period. Paul Barras served as a leader during this period after the arrest and execution of Maximilien de Robespierre.
This general brought an end to the Directory and brought about the Consulate. He later declared himself emperor of France in 1804.

Another subculture during the French revolutionary period were these perfume-wearing dandies that arose after the Thermidorian Reaction. They wielded clubs called “constitutions” and attacked sans-culottes during the White Terror.

bonuses.leadin: In his book The Holy Spirit, Your Financial Advisor, this pastor argued that God has a specific plan for financial success for each individual, which requires, unsurprisingly, giving this man money. For 10 points each:
answers: Creflo Dollar [or Creflo Augustus Dollar Jr; accept Michael Smith; prompt on just Smith]
prosperity theology [or prosperity gospel; or health and wealth gospel; or the gospel of success; prompt on seed faith]
idols [accept graven images or cult images; accept word forms such as idolatry; prompt on answers like false gods; prompt on statues]
parts: Name this Atlanta area televangelist and founder of the World Changers Church. This pastor also leads Arrow Records, and wrote the Christian self-help books Overcoming Fear and How to Trouble Your Trouble.

Creflo Dollar is a prominent proponent of this controversial theological belief, which holds that wealth is a sign of God's favor. Pastors who preach this belief often encourage their congregations to plant "seeds" in the form of money that they say God will use to create future wealth.

Due to its heavy emphasis on material wealth, prosperity theology has frequently been compared to the sin of worshipping these things. Examples of these images in the Old Testament include the Golden Calf and several representations of Ba'al.
answers_formatted: Creflo Dollar [or Creflo Augustus Dollar Jr; accept Michael Smith; prompt on just Smith]
prosperity theology [or prosperity gospel; or health and wealth gospel; or the gospel of success; prompt on seed faith]
idols [accept graven images or cult images; accept word forms such as idolatry; prompt on answers like false gods; prompt on statues]

bonuses.leadin: NOTE TO MODERATOR: Please read the answerline to the 1st part of this bonus carefullyDescription Acceptable. The right-hand side of the Mshatta Façade is notable for failing to adhere to this restriction and both the Pisa Griffin and Fountain of Lions support the belief that this restriction was softer in western Europe. For 10 points each:
answers: the restriction on depicting living beings in Islamic art [accept aniconism; accept any clear knowledge description mentioning not being able to show humans/animals/idols/God/Muhammad in Islamic art; prompt on partial answers with “in what religious tradition”]
parts: Name this restriction often cited as the basis for the prominence of calligraphy and intricate floral or geometric design patterns on the inside of certain religious buildings.
One of the finest examples of intricate geometric patterning in Islamic art can be found on the many arches within the hypostyle hall of this Andalusian city’s Great Mosque.

The influence of geometric design on Islamic architecture can readily be seen in these honeycomb-shaped ornamental vaults prominently featured in the domes, apses, and entranceways of many Islamic houses of worship.
answers_formatted: the restriction on depicting living beings in Islamic art [accept aniconism; accept any clear knowledge description mentioning not being able to show humans/animals/idols/God/Muhammad in Islamic art; prompt on partial answers with “in what religious tradition”]
acceptable: the restriction on depicting living beings in Islamic art

bonuses.leadin: As a child, the narrator of this book would write a giant symbol meaning “I think” over the pages of her diary. For 10 points each:
answers: graphic novels [or comic books; or comics]
parts: Name this autobiographical book by Alison Bechdel, who reflects on her own coming out and the life of her closeted gay father.
Like Marjane Satrapi’s Persepolis, Fun Home is a memoir told in this format. Ta-Nehisi Coates has written a series of this type about Black Panther.

Shortly before her father’s death, Alison leaves him a copy of a memoir by Kate Millett titled for this word. This is the last word in the title of a 1973 novel about Isadora, who longs to escape her boring marriage by having a “zipless” sexual encounter.

bonuses.leadin: When natural gas contains more than 4ppm of this compound at standard temperature and pressure it is referred to as “sour gas”. For 10 points each:
answers: petroleum naphtha [or virgin naphtha or straight-run naphtha or cracked naphtha]
parts: Name this compound that is reacted with diatomic oxygen in the Claus process for purifying natural gas and other by-products of crude oil refining.

The removal of elemental sulfur from crude oil via the Claus process makes use of a catalyst of either aluminum or one of this other metal. This element’s chloride is purified from its rutile ore in the Kroll process.

One of the major sources of sulfur in petroleum refining is from this intermediate hydrocarbon stream that is typically processed into high-octane gasoline after desulfurization. When this substance first comes out of a crude oil distillation unit it is called either “virgin” or “straight-run”.
answers_formatted: petroleum naphtha [or virgin naphtha or straight-run naphtha or cracked naphtha]

bonuses.leadin: Charles Herbert Allen, the first civilian-governor of this island, established a sugar empire based on this island, which grew into Domino Sugar. For 10 points each:
answers: gritos [or cries; accept word forms, such as cry or grito]
parts: Name this island whose governance was outlined in the Foraker Act. Pedro Albizu Campos opposed the movement to make this island the 51st State.

This governor-general of Puerto Rico during World War II was known as the “topman of FDR’s ‘Brain Trust’”. He was appointed Undersecretary of Agriculture and developed the AAA along with Henry Wallace.
Puerto Rican independence was galvanized in one of these events at Lares. Other events of this type occurred at Dolores and Ypiranga (“i-PEE-rahn-gah”).
answers_formatted: gritos [or cries; accept word forms, such as cry or grito]

bonuses.leadin: NOTE TO MODERATOR: do NOT reveal the subtitle of the first answerlineThis book criticizes the rise of "cognitive relativism" and warns students of philosophy and the humanities about charlatans who misuse scientific terms in meaningless ways. For 10 points each:
answers: Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals' Abuse of Science [or Impostures intellectuelles; or Intellectual Impostures]
postmodernism [accept word forms such as postmodernity; accept the postmodern condition]
parts: Name this book by Alan Sokal and Jean Bricmont, which was written as part of the "science wars" as a critique of several leading French intellectuals.

The subtitle of Fashionable Nonsense refers to the "abuse of science" by members of this philosophical movement. This movement included thinkers such as Jean-Francious Lyotard, who argued that this movement was characterized by the collapse of metanarratives in the wake of this movement's predecessor.

In Fashionable Nonsense, Sokal and Bricmont argued that this philosopher used "a great concentration of scientific terms, employed out of context and without any apparent logic." This philosopher was a frequent collaborator with Felix Guattari on books such as Capitalism and Schizophrenia.
answers_formatted: Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals' Abuse of Science [or Impostures intellectuelles; or Intellectual Impostures]
postmodernism [accept word forms such as postmodernity; accept the postmodern condition]
acceptable: Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals' Abuse of Science

bonuses.leadin: In a book which paired these rules with "morals," Harriet Martineau argued for a type of cultural relativism, while still claiming that these rules and morals have no meaning away from each other. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these rules, which govern social interactions according to societal expectations. When referring to the rules surrounding eating, these rules are often referred to as the "table" kind of this term.
This thinker outlined a sociological history of manners in his book The Civilizing Process. He also described the role of sports in civilization in his book The Quest for Excitement.

Manners are often divided into manners concerned with hygiene, courtesy, and this other concept, which describes acceptable behavior in a given social situation. Violations of this concept are less severe than violations of taboos or mores (“moor-ays”).

bonuses.leadin: George Dantzig demonstrated that the “unbounded” version of this problem could be solved with a greedy approximation algorithm. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this problem whose simpler “zero-one” version involves choosing whether an item of a given value and weight should be taken in the namesake object or left behind.

The knapsack problem was included by Richard Karp in his 1972 paper outlining the 21 classic problems in this complexity class. By definition, the solvability of a problem in this class will prove the solvability of every problem in its superclass of problems that are verifiable in polynomial time.

The first problem proven to be NP-complete by the Cook-Levin theorem involves the “satisfiability” of these logical expressions. Named for a British logician, these expressions can only take on values of “true” and “false”.

bonuses.leadin: David Malouf fictionalized this event in his novella An Imaginary Life. For 10 points each:
answers: Ovid’s exile [accept synonyms like banishment for “exile”; accept Publius Ovidius Naso for “Ovid”; prompt on just exile or equivalents by asking “Who was exiled?”]
parts: Name this event that may have been a result of the publication of Ars Amatoria. It mainly took place in the town of Tomis near the Black Sea.
After his exile, all of Ovid’s writings were banned from the libraries of Rome, including this 15-book epic poem detailing stories of transformation in Greek mythology.
At the end of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, this person’s soul is turned into a star. Aulus Hurtius added an eighth book to a nonfiction account by this man.
answers_formatted: Ovid’s exile [accept synonyms like banishment for “exile”; accept Publius Ovidius Naso for “Ovid”; prompt on just exile or equivalents by asking “Who was exiled?”]

bonuses.leadin: By definition, these curves represent the points at which the chemical potential for all components of a solution are equal in each phase. For 10 points each:
answers: Clausius-Clapeyron equation [accept Clapeyron equation; accept “relation” in place of “equation”]
heat of sublimation or enthalpy of sublimation [prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these curves that intersect spinodal curves at critical points.

For a coexistence curve separating two phases, this equation is used to compute the slope of the curve. This doubly-eponymous equation sets the natural log of pressure equal to enthalpy change over RT plus a constant.

For a gas in a Knudsen cell, the Clausius-Clapeyron equation can be used to calculate this quantity for the resulting solid as a function of vapor pressure and temperature. CO2 has a low value of 25 kilojoules per mole for this quantity.
answers_formatted: Clausius-Clapeyron equation [accept Clapeyron equation; accept “relation” in place of “equation”]
heat of sublimation or enthalpy of sublimation [prompt on partial answers]
acceptable: heat of sublimation or enthalpy of sublimation

bonuses.leadin: This character’s logical method of deduction is contrasted with that of his more imaginative companion, Hastings. For 10 points each:
answers: Agatha Christie [or Dame Agatha Mary Clarissa Miller]
Styles Court [accept The Mysterious Affair at Styles]
parts: Name this Belgian detective who uses his “little grey cells” to solve mysteries.
Hercule Poirot was created by this mystery writer, who is, according to UNESCO, the most translated author in the world.
Poirot deduces that Emily Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband Albert in a novel partially titled for this location. Poirot dies at this location in the novel Curtain.

bonuses.leadin: A small child in a white coat pulls a sled toward other kids playing in the snow in an Impressionist painting of this location “in the winter” by William Glackens. For 10 points each:
answers: Central Park [prompt on New York (City) or NYC or Manhattan]
parts: Name this location where children can be seen frolicking in a Post-Impressionist painting by Maurice Prendergast. More recently, an iconic photo by Diane Arbus shows a child with a toy hand grenade in this location.
Glackens and Prendergast were among the numerous American artists with works at this influential 1913 Exhibition in New York. This event was the first modern art exhibition in the United States.
This other member of The Eight from Greenwich Village exhibited many of his characteristically realistic street scenes at the 1913 Armory Show. He also painted The Spielers and The Wrestlers.

bonuses.leadin: A leader during this period was known as “72 Cannon” because he shot 72 cannons into the sky repeatedly until it rained in Shandong. For 10 points each:
answers: Yuan Shikai [accept Hongxian Emperor; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this period. This period was dominated by its namesake leaders, who ruled individual provinces as separate states after the collapse of the Qing Dynasty.

The warlord era began in earnest after the death of this leader, who accepted Japan’s “Twenty-One Demands”. This warlord bailed out the Qing government during the Wuchang Uprising with his Beiyang Army.
The warlord era ended with the ascension of this generalissimo. This KMT leader took over after the death of Sun Yat-Sen.

bonuses.leadin: In the music video for this album's lead single, the singer is on a date with a man who responds "oh literally either" when asked if he is comparing the singer to Lucy Liu or Sandra Oh. For 10 points each:
answers: SAWAYAMA [do not accept or prompt on answers that mention "Rina"]
United Kingdom [or UK; or Great Britain; prompt on England]
parts: Name this 2020 album whose lead single, "STFU!," describes the experience of microaggressions by Asian women. This album also features the single "XS" (excess), which criticises the spending of capitalism in light of climate change.

During the summer of 2019, Rina Sawayama opened on tour for this other singer. who recorded and released her album How I'm Feeling Now during the Covid-19 lockdown and this singer included the singles "Blame It On Your Love" and  "1999" on her self titled 2019 album.
Rina Sawayama and Charli XCX are both residents of this country, whose other resident contemporary pop artists include Dua Lipa and Adele.

bonuses.leadin: Genome-wide association studies, like the International HapMap Project, are commonly used to study this effect. For 10 points each:
answers: genetic linkage [accept word forms like “two genes are linked”]
lod score [accept logarithm of the odds score]
parts: Name this effect in which genes close to one another on the same chromosome are often inherited together. Eye color and wing length in fruit flies violate Mendel’s Law of Independent Assortment due to this effect.

Earlier techniques for observing genetic linkage typically made use of molecular markers like SNPs (“snips”) to map these regions of DNA. These regions typically correspond to continually-varying traits like height, as opposed to discrete traits like eye color.

When analyzing a QTL map, this statistical measure appears on the y-axis. Values of 3 or more for this metric are generally accepted to mean that two genes are likely near one another and likely to be linked.
answers_formatted: genetic linkage [accept word forms like “two genes are linked”]
acceptable: word forms like “two genes are linked”

bonuses.leadin: Traditions including the “wooden horse”, which entailed tying a criminal to a wooden frame and parading around the village, inspired these events. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these 1839-1843 riots during which farmers dressed up as its namesake women and destroyed toll-gates to protest unfair taxation.
The Rebecca Riots occurred in this region. Owen Glendower led an earlier revolt from this region, whose last independent king was Llewellyn the Last.
The Rebecca Riots were partially sparked by the failures of this 1834 law aimed to provide relief for its namesake people. This law largely failed despite increasing workhouse employment.

bonuses.leadin: Jacques Rivette’s film La Belle Noiseuse is based on this story. For 10 points each:
answers: sex worker [or courtesan; or prostitute; accept word forms]
parts: Name this story by Honore de Balzac about the master painter Frenhofer, who sets fire to his studio after Poussin (“poo-SAN”) and Porbus are underwhelmed by a portrait he took ten years to finish.
“The Unknown Masterpiece” was included in a giant collection of Balzac’s works titled for a “Human” example of this genre. The title is an allusion to Dante’s “Divine” work named for this genre.

Balzac wrote a series of novels in his Human Comedy about the “Splendor and Progress” about a character with this job nicknamed “the Torpedo.” The title of Guy de Maupassant’s story “Ball of Fat” refers to a character with this profession.

bonuses.leadin: One of the first usages of the word “baroque” in reference to music was in a criticism of this opera by Jean-Phillipe Rameau, which was also attacked by supporters of Jean-Baptiste Lully. For 10 points each:
answers: Hippolyte et Aricie [or Hippolytus and Aricia]
parts: Name this mythologically-inspired opera. Rameau cut sections like the “Trio des Parques” and the aria “Cruelle mère des amours,” from this opera for being dissonant and difficult to perform, but eventually put them back after gaining fame.
In the so-called “War of the Buffoons”, the merits of Italian opera were compared to opera from this other country, the home of Jean-Baptiste Lully and Jean-Philippe Rameau.

These male singers with very high vocal range had leading roles in many Baroque operas, such as Handel’s Giulio Cesare and Cavalli’s Giasone. These singers fell out of favor in the late 18th century due to changes in societal and musical tastes, and their roles are now performed by countertenors.

bonuses.leadin: The town of Fort Navan is alternatively named for this woman’s “pair”, her children Fir and Fial. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this woman, who was forced to race against the horses of the king of Ulster while pregnant. Her subsequent curse afflicted the men of Ulster with pregnancy pains during the Cattle Raid of Cooley.

Macha, along with Nemain and Badb, was an aspect of this tripartite war goddess who opposed Cu Chulainn in various animal forms, such as the raven. She appeared to doomed men as “the washer at the ford.”
The legends of Macha and the Morrigan comprise part of this Celtic island's mythology, along with characters such as Queen Medb and Finn MacCool. This island is also home to the Ulster Cycle.
